conclusion: To express van der Waals constants a and b in terms of critical temperature Tc and critical pressure Pc using critical point conditions.
Van der Waals equation is given by (P + a/V^2)(V - b) = RT.
At the critical point, first derivative of pressure with respect to volume is zero.
At the critical point, second derivative of pressure with respect to volume is zero.
Pressure, volume, and temperature are at their critical values Pc, Vc, and Tc.
Express van der Waals equation at the critical point as (Pc + a/Vc^2)(Vc - b) = RTc.
Differentiate van der Waals equation with respect to V at constant T and set first derivative to zero at critical point.
Differentiate the first derivative with respect to V again and set second derivative to zero at critical point.
Solve the system of equations derived from critical point conditions.
Known critical point relations: Vc = 3b, Pc = a/27b^2, Tc = 8a/27Rb.
Express a in terms of Pc and b as a = 27b^2 Pc.
Express Tc in terms of b and Pc as Tc = 8bPc/R.
Express b in terms of Tc and Pc as b = RTc/8Pc.
Substitute b back into expression for a to get a = 27(R^2 Tc^2)/(64 Pc).
Final answer: van der Waals constants a = 27(R^2 Tc^2)/(64 Pc) and b = RTc/8Pc.
